title: Rugby World Cup: Scotland considering legal action over typhoon-threatened Japan clash
text:
A decision over Scotland’s clash with Japan will be made on Saturday (Picture: Getty)

Scotland believe they have a legal case to block World Rugby from cancelling their World Cup clash against Japan as it goes against the ‘integrity’ of the tournament.

Typhoon Hagibis has already forced two matches to be cancelled and the decision over Scotland’s clash with Japan was set to be made on Saturday, 24 hours before the game was proposed to go ahead.

Every opportunity is being given to ensure Scotland’s clash with Japan goes ahead as its a winner-takes-all affair in Yokohama and both sides have been promised every measure will be taken to keep the game on.

But, with the continuing threat of a cancellation, SRU chief executive Mark Dodson says they have legal opinion that ‘unravels’ World Rugby ruling.

However, every opportunity is being given to ensure Scotland’s clash with Japan goes ahead as its a winner-takes-all affair in Yokohama.

But, with the continuing threat of a cancellation, SRU chief executive Mark Dodson says they have legal opinion that ‘unravels’ World Rugby ruling.

While Dodson acknowledges the clear threat the typhoon poses to supporters and participants alike, he has questioned why a cancellation is the first option World Rugby are considering.

Cancelling the game means Scotland and Japan will both receive two points for a draw, meaning the Scots will be knocked out of the tournament.

Instead, Dodson wants the authorities to look at holding the game at a later date or even at a different location.

‘The common sense approach to this is to play the game 24 hours later on perfect safety where we can make sure that the pool stages are completed, and the sporting integrity of the tournament remains intact,’ he added.
